newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Former South Korean diplomat jailed for forgery.
newsitem.headline: Former South Korean diplomat jailed for forgery.

text.p: A Seoul court on Tuesday sentenced former South Korean diplomat Choi Seung-jin to two years in jail for forging a foreign ministry document, court officials said.
"The defendant, as a civil servant, forged a document, thereby damaging the reputation of the nation and the honour of the ministry," judge Shim Sang-chol told the court.
Court officials said Choi, a former vice-consul at the South Korean embassy in New Zealand, confessed to the charge.
The bogus document instructed South Korean embassies worldwide to analyse the electoral systems in their country of posting for ways in which governments could justify postponing an election.

Choi said he forged the document because he wanted to expose what he believed was a plot by the government of President Kim Young-sam to postpone local-level elections last year because the ruling party feared defeat, court officials said.
The polls were held last year as scheduled.

The case caused a political storm last year when Kwon Roh-kap, a lawmaker aligned with the main opposition National Congress for New Politics, raised the allegations against the government in parliament after Choi sent him the forged document.
Kwon was indicted in May on libel charges for attacking the government based on the contents of the document, which prosecutors said he knew were faked.
After Choi was found out, he was sacked and ordered home, but applied for refugee status in New Zealand.
Earlier this year, New Zealand turned down his application and deported him to South Korea where he was immediately arrested.
New Zealand's political opposition cried foul, saying Choi had been sacrificed to keep relations with Seoul smooth.
South Korea is New Zealand's fifth-largest export market and second-largest source of tourist arrivals.
